html:
1.5.25  3:00 am   what is your favorite misspelling 

      ih

1.5.25  1:29 am   Let's say my family has an extremely violent pet goose named Fransisco that has a constant thirst for human blood. How would one deal with that?

      write a sitcom 'loosely' based on that where you keep absolutely everything the same except you change everyone's name by 1 letter

1.5.25  1:11 am   a couple years ago i distinctly remember reading = a response on here that went something along the lines of "use as few chords as possible when writing a song"

     that's really not something i would say. there may have been some very specific context where that would be appropriate, but it really does not sound like something i would say. various times in my life i have heard people say that kind of thing and it doesn't quite sit well with me. that being said, the opposite doesn't sit well either of course

     --i've been haunted by this ever since.

     please don't give me credit for that. this is something you either thought of yourself, or heard from someone else (a lot of people say it actually) probably trying to address their concerns that people may be using the opposite strategy, which doesn't really make sense either

      the more i dig into your music, the more i realize just how much of it is founded on the most rudimentary I's, IV's, and V's, despite all the crazy fills and modulations.

     i think you're looking in the wrong place. in fact, just the order and pattern to which you listed the chords you just listed, gives me a clue that you might be looking in the wrong place for this

      when i write, i often find myself getting distracted by the more lush and colorful sound of upper extensions,

     i find you can't actually prove which part extends from which and when

      as well as lots of dramatic chord movements.

     how do you feel about melodies

      i've trained my brain to prioritize those kinds of sounds, and it feels like anything else sounds, regrettably, "plain". but i feel oftentimes that it undermines my music in the grand scale of things; i'd do ANYTHING to go back in time to before i was so mired in jazz theory.

     you seem to be walking backwards all the time. all this 'how to not'. sounds like youve got a case of the 'how to nots'. so 'how to not have a case of the how to nots?' well actually i think in your case, hear me out, ........ i think you should try to write the most academically advanced musical composition the world has ever seen. (seen?..... wait no actually yes.)

      do you have any advice on achieving this sort of "harmony nirvana" that you seem to have? it's as if you know perfectly where to place all the surprising and exciting harmonic moments without compromising simplicity.

     i'm just pursuing what excites me most. i took a random quasi-satirical guess just now at what might excite you, but that might be unfair.... the point is, i see you back-stepping away from anything that might truly thrill you, and then backstepping back away from the alternative because of course it doesn't thrill you enough. Whatever your thrills may be, ....... you must go toward them. or, if it's more thrilling, do a fake-out and go briefly away from them and then slam back toward them, and so on

     tl;dr: as a theory-obsessed berklee dropout, how can i learn the confidence to use more "basic" or "boring" chords in my music?

     why settle for just scratching the surface..... go for a world record. make the most boring song ever made. heck, you'd be famous immediately if you actually achieved that

1.4.25  7:11 pm   Decided on a whim today to take a different path than I normally do on a walk. When I went down it I kept thinking to myself "Why don't I go down here? Why haven't I incorporated this into my normal route yet? This is nice." It got me wondering why people get so stuck in a routine or become reluctant to try different things. Even when those things are relatively easy to try. Have you ever experienced that?

      yes i have

1.3.25  10:56 am   I like that thing that happens sometimes in songs where an unfinished lyric is repeated in kind of an unresolved melody, then the lyric finishes climacticly as the melody/harmony resolves. Usually happens with the title line of the song and at the end of the song.

A couple examples that come to mind are Jingle Bell Rock ("That's the jingle bell, that's the jingle bell,  that's the jiiiinnnnggleee belllll rooooockkkk!"). There's also this live version of You Make Me Feel So Young where Sinatra ends it with "You make me feel so, you make me feeeeel so... Oh, you!... Make me feel, sooooooo..... (crazy horn section line).... yooouuunnnnng!"

I want to come up with a name for this thing?

     you're a little late for that...... the vast majority of all working musicians have been calling this a 'tag', for at least a century in my estimate

      Also, can you think of any more examples?

     trillions. for huge parts of the 20th century, it seems like all songs did that. maybe slightly less often nowadays but it still gets used all the time. heck i do it in my own songs. Or any time i'm listening to a song, especially if it might not be from an era or context where you might expect a tag, and then they start doing a tag, i say out loud, to myself or whoever's around, 'taggin it!'
